results.headline: Serious Adulthood Waiting to Happen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The New Year

results.summary_short: Dating, flirting and fighting boredom, with a dying father in the background.

results.headline: The Man, the Magazine, the Mansion: The World According to Hef
results.display_title: Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hugh Hefner: Playboy, Activist and Rebel

results.summary_short: A documentary about Hugh Hefner says that beyond the hedonism, there is an equal-rights advocate who is overlooked.

results.headline: How Can You Enjoy Your Own Funeral? For Starters, Don’t Die

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Get Low

results.summary_short: Aaron Schneider directs Robert Duvall in the true story of a man who wants to enjoy his own funeral.

results.headline: Charming Socialites, Although Palm Beach Is Still Out of Reach

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Extra Man

results.summary_short: A tale of an older asexual gadabout, a throwback to the age of “the confirmed bachelor,” and a young man who hopes to be a writer.

results.headline: Telling a Soldier’s Tale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Dry Land

results.summary_short: Ryan Piers Williams directs a story of a soldier who returns from Iraq.

results.headline: What? We Might Be the Real Losers?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dinner for Schmucks

results.summary_short: “Dinner for Schmucks” is in some ways an exemplary modern Hollywood comedy.

results.headline: Getting the Old Band Back Together

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Concert

results.summary_short: “The Concert,” by the Romanian director Radu Mihaileanu, is a kind of French-Russian answer to “The Producers.”

results.headline: Playing With Phantoms in the Northwest Woods

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie St. Cloud

results.summary_short: In a melodrama touched by the supernatural, Zac Efron cares for his dead younger brother.

results.headline: When Pets Reach Across the Aisle
results.display_title: Cats & Dogs: Revenge of Kitty Galore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cats & Dogs: Revenge of Kitty Galore

results.summary_short: “Cats & Dogs: The Revenge of Kitty Galore” is a spy-and-action-film pastiche that charms less than its predecessor, “Cats & Dogs” (2001).

results.headline: The Difficulties of Escaping the Past

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Spoken Word

results.summary_short: “Spoken Word” follows characters with painful pasts and fertile minds.

results.headline: Shades of ‘Happiness,’ Appalling and Funny

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life During Wartime

results.summary_short: Todd Solondz’s sort-of sequel to his “Happiness” concerns three sisters whose quest for contentment sits at the center of this episodic film.

results.headline: A Hurricane of Misery

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Slingshot

results.summary_short: Brillante Ma. Mendoza’s 2007 feature “Tirador” (“Slingshot”) is only now being released in the United States.

results.headline: Spies, Spider Venom and Sex Appeal

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salt

results.summary_short: In “Salt,” Angelina Jolie is a reminder that even in an era of technological overkill, movie stars matter.

results.headline: Mismatched Sisters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ramona and Beezus

results.summary_short: With “Ramona and Beezus,” parents may be happy to see a movie for children that doesn’t involve wizards, vampires or action figures.

results.headline: Fighting His Country to Keep His Farmland

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mugabe and the White African

results.summary_short: Lucy Bailey and Andrew Thompson’s documentary examines a farmer’s efforts to hold on to his property in the face of land seizures.

results.headline: French Connection: K.G.B. Colonel Plotting to Break the Isolation

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Farewell

results.summary_short: Emir Kusturica and Guillaume Canet star in Christian Carion’s espionage drama, about the real-life Vladimir Vetrov, whose code name was “Farewell.”

results.headline: Nuclear Fears

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Countdown to Zero

results.summary_short: Paying to see “Countdown to Zero” is like tipping a fortuneteller to predict the manner of your death.

results.headline: A Slice of Midwestern Mumblecore

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Audrey the Trainwreck

results.summary_short: “Audrey the Trainwreck” suggests Robert Altman without any of Altman’s instincts for character and poetry.

results.headline: A Friend, an Artist and a Personal Interview

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jean-Michel Basquiat: The Radiant Child

results.summary_short: Tamra Davis’s documentary, a romantic depiction of Jean-Michel Basquiat, blazingly brings to life the artist’s work and its cultural context.

results.headline: More to Life
results.display_title: To age or not to age

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of To age or not to age

results.summary_short: Robert Kane Pappas’s digressive documentary “To Age or Not to Age” features scientists working on ways to control longevity.
